Situation1: They actively help a mentee navigate a challenging project with regular check-ins and feedback.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story: I glanced at my phone, seeing a message from my mentee: “Can you review my project draft before the meeting in an hour?” I’d promised to help her through this tough phase, and she was counting on my feedback. But right now, I was behind the register at the grocery store, scanning items for a small line of customers. “Hi, how are you today?” I said, forcing a smile as I rang up a woman’s groceries. My mind kept drifting to the project, wondering if my mentee would feel abandoned if I didn’t reply soon. The next customer stepped up, and I greeted him, but my thoughts were split—half on the beeping scanner, half on the draft I hadn’t read. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me: the expectation to be present and helpful for my mentee, and the need to be friendly and efficient for each customer. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role needed me more in this moment, feeling the tension build with every item I scanned.
